Name: Anna Grace Prine
Address: 12, Bradworth, Sask.
Birthplace: Greenock, Scotland

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1904
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Bradworth, Sask.
   Where had you been living before that? Pincourt, Quebec
   For how many people did you prepare meals? Six People
   How far was it to your nearest store? Six miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Flour, Tea, Sugar, Salt, Rolled Oats, Cold Soup, Coffee, Syrup and Beans.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

   How much did you use? 100 lb. per week
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50

   Whole wheat flour? ...............................................................

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

In the early days, groceries were purchased from a wholesale firm in Winnipeg.
Storage of foods was a problem in the early days, as the shacks had only small cellars. Some farmers had root cellars stored up in the inside. This served as a refrigerator to keep milk, butter and meat in the summer.
These outside cellars were also intended for shelter in the event of bad storms, cyclones etc.,
You are now more prepared for food now.

Bread mostly bought.

Unworked Grains used.

Gluehie & Yaw Stoves.

Pepys, Alumunium & Still Vials.

1917 - Baker's Bread.

1925 - Marwood Creams.

1945 - Cake, Biscuit, Tea Mixes.

When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible.)

Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and nourishing foods in your area during pioneer days in eastern Canada.

Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems or stories, shortages and other details. (Use back of paper if more space is needed.)

In the early days, groceries were purchased from a wholesale firm in Winnipeg.

Storage of foods was a problem in the early days, so the shelves had only small cellars.

Some farmers had root cellars stored up in their animals. This served as a refrigerator to keep milk, butter, and much in summer.

These outside cellars were also utilized for shells in the event of bad storms.
